title: 107_s1293
content: The Act titled "Climate Change Tax Amendments of 2001" includes a permanent tax credit for research and development related to reducing, avoiding, or sequestering greenhouse gas emissions. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for an exception for certain research expenses related to reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The amendment applies to expenses incurred after the enactment of the Act, contingent on the Climate Change Risk Management Act of 2001 becoming law. SEC. 3. TAX CREDIT FOR GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS FACILITIES. This section introduces a new tax credit for greenhouse gas emissions facilities under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit for greenhouse gas emissions facilities under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is based on the qualified investment in a facility that reduces greenhouse gas emissions compared to the replaced facility. The tax credit for greenhouse gas emissions facilities is based on qualified investments in facilities that reduce emissions, use the same type of fuel as the replaced facility, allow for depreciation, and meet performance standards jointly prescribed by the Secretary and the Secretary of Energy. The applicable percentage is one-half of the percentage reduction. The tax credit for greenhouse gas emissions facilities is based on qualified investments in facilities that reduce emissions. The applicable percentage is one-half of the reduction in emissions reported and certified under the Energy Policy Act of 1992. Qualified investment refers to the basis of a greenhouse gas emissions facility placed in service by the taxpayer, limited to the production capacity of the facility being replaced. The tax credit for greenhouse gas emissions facilities is based on qualified investments in facilities that reduce emissions. The taxable year is increased by qualified progress expenditures for progress expenditure property being constructed by or for the taxpayer. For tax purposes, 'qualified progress expenditures' refer to the amount chargeable to capital account for property construction. 'Qualified progress expenditures' for non-self-constructed property are payments made to another person for construction. 'Self-constructed property' is where more than half of construction expenditures are directly made by the taxpayer. Construction expenditures for non-self-constructed property include reconstruction and erection, and only the construction of greenhouse gas emissions facilities is considered. An election can be made under this subsection as per the Secretary's guidelines. An election can be made under this subsection for the taxable year and subsequent years, as prescribed by the Secretary. Once made, the election cannot be revoked without the Secretary's consent. Special rules apply for greenhouse gas emissions facilities regarding the investment tax credit. The tax credit for a greenhouse gas emissions facility is calculated based on the remaining years of depreciation. If the facility is disposed of, the year of disposition is considered a year of remaining depreciation. Special rules apply for progress expenditures on such properties. The tax credit for a greenhouse gas emissions facility is calculated based on remaining years of depreciation, with special rules for progress expenditures. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include defining qualified investments and updating section 50(a)(4) and the table of sections for subpart E of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the enactment date. A study will be conducted on additional incentives for voluntary reduction, avoidance, or sequestration of greenhouse gas emissions. Expenditures are considered voluntary and non-recoupable if not recoupable from generated revenues or financial incentive programs. Within 6 months, a joint report to Congress will be submitted with recommendations for legislative action. The curr_chunk discusses the scope and impact of incentives for greenhouse gas emissions reduction, emphasizing the need for a level playing field for all entities, including non-profit organizations. The Secretaries of Treasury and Energy are tasked with studying additional measures to provide economic incentives for non-profit entities. The Secretaries of Treasury and Energy will report to Congress on the study results and recommendations for legislative action regarding economic incentives for greenhouse gas emissions facilities.
